channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Restaurant Patron’s Behavior Is Panned
item.description: Twitter outrage and an investigation were ignited because a privileged young woman called on her father’s government agency to shut down a Mexico City restaurant after she did not get the table she wanted.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: After Bombing, American Ties With Russia Improve
item.description: The White House indicated Russia had been cooperative after the Boston attack, though Russia has not been able to provide valuable intelligence about the suspects.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: As Election Nears, Ahmadinejad’s Critics Pile On
item.description: Politicians and others have been taking more frequent swings at President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and his handling of the economy six weeks before the election to pick a successor.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad in Venezuela earlier this month.

item.title: Grim Economics Shape France’s Military Spending
item.description: The government froze the defense budget but will reallocate resources, devoting more to high-tech equipment and cutting 10 percent of military jobs.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Woman Loses Appeal for Assisted Death in Ireland
item.description: The Supreme Court rejected the argument that the decriminalization of suicide in Irish law necessarily conferred a right to die.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: Afghan Leader Confirms Cash Deliveries by C.I.A.
item.description: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan described the bags of cash dropped off at his office for a decade as a “small amount,” though he offered few other details.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Off-the-books cash delivered directly to President Karzai’s office shows payments on a vast scale.

item.title: Massacre in Nigeria Spurs Outcry Over Military Tactics
item.description: A gruesome assault that left scores of villagers dead has been blamed by survivors on revenge-seeking soldiers and has brought withering criticism at home and abroad.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Houses were burned in what Nigerian authorities said was heavy fighting between security forces and Islamist militants in Baga, a fishing town on the shores of Lake Chad, last week.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 29
item.description: People waiting for Prime Minister Manmohan Singh to address a Congress Party campaign rally in Bangalore, Karnataka.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: People waiting for Prime Minister Manmohan Singh to address a Congress Party campaign rally in Bangalore, Karnataka, ahead of state assembly elections scheduled to be held on May 5.

item.title: Syrian Prime Minister Escapes Assassination Bid
item.description: A car bomb in Damascus, which appeared to target Prime Minister Wael Nader al-Halqi, was the latest in a series of attempts against high-level officials.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: One of the damaged vehicles following an explosion believed to have targeted Prime Minister Wael al-Halqi in Damascus on Monday.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Chinese Tourist Boat HeadsToward Disputed Islands
item.description: Vietnam criticized a cruise ship’s trip to the Paracels in the South China Sea, arguing that Vietnam’s sovereignty is “incontestable.”
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Billions of Cellphones Polluting the World
item.description: As people in emerging economies adopt more mobile technology, global metal needs will be three to nine times larger than all the metals currently used in the world.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE
item.media:description: Old mobile phones were on display at the CeBit trade fair in Hanover, Germany in March.

item.title: Three Car Bomb Blasts Kill at Least 23 in Iraq
item.description: At least 23 people were killed in Iraq on Monday in a series of car bombs in Shi’ite Muslim areas and militant attacks, medics and police sources said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: U.S. and Mexico, Amid Drug War, Spurn an Informant
item.description: Luis Octavio López Vega, a former adviser to a Mexican drug czar and a D.E.A. informant, has been in hiding as Mexican officials seek his arrest and American officials have cut ties with him.
item.dc:creator: By GINGER THOMPSON
item.media:description: Luis Octavio López Vega, left, once a police chief in Mexico, played a leading role in what is widely considered the biggest drug-trafficking case in Mexican history.

item.title: India Ink: Guinness Record Holder Dies Performing Stunt Over Teesta River
item.description: Sailendra Nath Roy tried to cross a West Bengal river using his hair.
item.dc:creator: By SRUTHI GOTTIPATI
item.media:description: Sailendra Nath Roy, a Guinness World Record holder, attempting to cross the river Teesta on the outskirts of Siliguri in West Bengal on Sunday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: International Schools Boom as More Seek Education in English
item.description: There are now 6,400 international schools all over the world, with new ones opening all the time. A job fair in London is a snapshot of Western teachers desperate for a job meeting up with institutions desperate to fill their ranks. Have you studied or taught at an international school? Tell us your experiences.
item.dc:creator: By JOYCE LAU
item.media:description: Teachers lined up at an interview sign-up session at the Council of International Schools' recruitment fair in London.

item.title: Livin’ La Vida Rio
item.description: David Alan Harvey’s “Based On a True Story”

item.title: India Ink: At Madurai’s Chithirai Thiruvizha Festival, Crowds, Flowers and a Golden Horse
item.description: A spring festival celebrates Parvati’s marriage to Shiva.
item.dc:creator: By DEREK BROWN

item.title: Letter from Europe: An Alliance Diminished, but Still Vital
item.description: After President Obama’s visit to Jerusalem last month, there were high hopes in Washington and NATO for a turning point in relations between Israel and Turkey.
item.dc:creator: By JUDY DEMPSEY

item.title: 10 Dead or Missing in Ship Collision Off Greece
item.description: The cause of the accident, which involved two cargo ships off the coast of the Peloponnese region, was unclear.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: India Ink: After Etihad Deal, India’s Airlines May Attract More Foreign Interest
item.description: India’s cash-strapped airlines, including SpiceJet and Indigo, might attract investors.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: From left: Hameed Ali, acting C.E.O. of Jet Airways, James Hogan, president and C.E.O. of Etihad Airways, Naresh Goyal, chairman of Jet Airways with James Rigney, chief financial officer of Etihad Airways, on Wednesday after the deal between the two airlines was announced.

item.title: Explosion Hits Central Prague
item.description: An explosion in central Prague, likely caused by gas, injured as many as 40 people and neighboring buildings, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: The scene of an explosion in downtown Prague, Czech Republic, on Monday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Farewell to an Enigmatic Chinese Bishop
item.description: Bishop Aloysius Jin Luxian, whose funeral was held Monday in Shanghai, walked a tightrope trying to balance the interests of Beijing and Rome.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Bishop Aloysius Jin Luxian, who died Saturday, with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany at St. Ignatius Cathedral in Shanghai in 2006.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 29
item.description: The death toll mounts after the building collapse in Bangladesh; the C.I.A. in Afghanistan; challenges for Italy’s new prime minister; Cairo rebuilds.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Off-the-books cash delivered directly to President Karzai’s office shows payments on a vast scale.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Confidence Issues Linger as the Dreamliner Soars Again
item.description: Boeing’s Dreamliner is back in the air, but questions linger about the cause of the battery overheating, the technology fixes – and confidence.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A Boeing 787 of All Nippon Airways landing at the end of a test flight at Haneda International Airport in Tokyo on Sunday.

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills 9 in Pakistan
item.description: In the latest episode of violence before elections in May, an attacker detonated his explosives near a police patrol car in Peshawar.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN and DECLAN WALSH
